sections.title: Conversation: Booking a Hotel Room
sections.audioTranscript:
Receptionist: Good morning, Maple Leaf Hotel. How can I help you?
Customer: Hi, I'd like to book a room for next weekend. That’s the 14th to the 16th.
Receptionist: Certainly. Would you prefer a single or double room?
Customer: A double, please. Is breakfast included?
Receptionist: Yes, breakfast is included in all room types. The price is $120 per night.
Customer: Great. And do you have parking available?
Receptionist: Yes, but you need to reserve a parking spot in advance.
Customer: Okay, I’ll need parking for one car.
Receptionist: Perfect. May I have your full name?
Customer: John Miller.
Receptionist: Thank you. Your booking is confirmed.

questions.question: What dates is the customer booking?
Which type of room does the customer want?
Breakfast is included in the booking.
How much does one night cost?
What must be reserved in advance?
What is the customer’s name?

sections.title: Monologue: University Library Orientation
sections.audioTranscript:
Welcome to the Westside University Library. In this short introduction, I’ll explain the main services we offer. The library is open from 8 AM to 10 PM on weekdays and from 10 AM to 6 PM on weekends. You can borrow up to ten books at a time, and the loan period is three weeks. Late returns will result in a fine of $1 per day.
The library also includes group study rooms. These must be booked online at least 24 hours in advance. Printing and scanning services are available on the ground floor, and wireless internet is free for all students.

questions.question: What time does the library open on weekdays?
How many books can a student borrow at once?
Students must pay to use the Wi-Fi.
How long is the book loan period?
Where are the printing services located?
What must be booked 24 hours in advance?

sections.title: Conversation: Students Discussing a Research Project
sections.audioTranscript:
Alice: We need to choose a topic for our environmental science project.
Ben: How about plastic pollution?
Alice: That’s common. Maybe we should do renewable energy instead.
Ben: Solar power?
Alice: Yes, but let’s focus on small-scale solar panels used in rural communities.
Ben: Good idea. Who should present the introduction?
Alice: I can do it. You can explain the data analysis.
Ben: Sure. And we need to finish the draft by Friday.
Alice: Friday is too soon. Can we make it Sunday?
Ben: Okay, Sunday works.

questions.question: What topic do the students finally choose?
options: C. Solar energy in rural areas

questions.question: Who will present the introduction?
Who is responsible for data analysis?
The students must submit the final report on Friday.
What day is the new deadline?
Why do they reject the topic of plastic pollution?

sections.title: Lecture: The History of the Telephone
sections.audioTranscript:
Today’s lecture will cover the history of the telephone. The first practical telephone was invented by Alexander Graham Bell in 1876. Early telephones used wired connections, and communication was limited to short distances.
In the 20th century, the introduction of automatic telephone exchanges improved call quality and made the system faster. By the 1980s, mobile phones appeared, although they were large and expensive.
The 21st century brought smartphones, combining telecommunication with computing power. Modern smartphones now include high-speed internet, cameras, and advanced applications, transforming global communication.

questions.question: Who invented the first practical telephone?
When was the telephone invented?
Early telephones were limited by:
Automatic telephone exchanges improved call quality.
Mobile phones in the 1980s were:
Name one feature of modern smartphones.
What has transformed global communication?
